content.description:
Find the beautiful looking finger seam splitting the face 80' off the deck next to a friendly pine tree. Start in the obvious corner stepping on knobs and jamming up the crack. Continue up past loose and breaking rock finding pro where you can. Pull some shrubs from the crack and pray your footholds don't break until you pull onto the ledge with a single bolt.

Here you are rewarded with a fantastic finger crack with perfect locks to a ledge. The fun remains as you hand and fist jam past the pine tree to a 2 bolt anchor with chains.
content.protection: Gear to 3. Thin cams useful at the cruxy finger section.
content.location: right around the corner, down-slope from the bubble wall. Look for the single bolt above a ledge with a perfect finger seam going up.

content.description: Fun pocket pulling on the bubbly face. Pinch big sandy pockets and maneuver up the interesting face. The main variation meanders left at the 4th bolt to clip a 5th and 6th in the groove. There is a decent run-out between these two bolts but the climbing is secure. The crux seems to be the move reaching the anchors.
content.protection: 7 bolts to 2 bolt anchor. alpine draws useful to reduce rope drag.
content.location: starts at the low bolt in the middle of the bubble wall.

content.description:
To left side of the bubble wall is a sexy off-width crack in a corner. Hand stack and stem up a cruxy 5.9 start to some fun pocket pulling. After the fun climbing is over, the route continues up loose and crumbling rock over precariously stacked death blocks to a dead tree. If you touch one of these and send the pile trundling down you may kill your belayer. The anchor is indeed old but looked solid enough to rap from.

A smarter, and more enjoyable way to climb this route would be to skip the choss and traverse right to the tiny bubbles anchor.
content.protection: Wide gear to 5. Tri-cams if you want to protect the easy pocket pulling. Alpine draws useful to extend the bolts.
content.location: The right arching crack in the dihedral, immediately left of the bubbles.
